summary: This document is an email chain from October 2019 between attorneys at the Marsh Law Firm and U.S. Attorney's Office personnel regarding a request for urgent assistance to bring an Israeli citizen, a victim of long-term sex trafficking, into the United States. The victim is alleged to have information relevant to the Jeffrey Epstein investigation, including a claim of being raped as a child at Epstein's New York mansion. The correspondence details the legal and logistical hurdles in obtaining a visa for the witness and the immediate threats to her safety.

persons.name: Jennifer Freeman
persons.context: Attorney with the Marsh Law Firm PLLC representing the Israeli victim. She is the primary correspondent requesting U.S. government assistance to bring her client into the country to provide information on the Epstein case.

persons.name: Paul G. Cassell
persons.context: Professor who facilitated the initial contact between the Marsh Law Firm and the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding the victim's case.

persons.name: James R. Marsh
persons.context: Attorney with the Marsh Law Firm PLLC copied on the correspondence regarding the victim's case.

persons.name: Robert Y. Lewis
persons.context: Attorney with the Marsh Law Firm PLLC copied on the correspondence regarding the victim's case.

persons.name: Dr. Silberg
persons.context: Medical doctor who has been assisting the victim, receiving evidence from her, and attempting to transmit information to law enforcement agencies in the U.S. and Canada.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the owner of the Manhattan mansion where the victim alleges she was raped as a child. Central figure in the investigation for which the victim claims to have information.

persons.name: Joseph Karo
persons.context: Name recalled by the victim as being mentioned during her time at the alleged location of abuse (Epstein's mansion).

persons.name: Yoav Gil
persons.context: Name recalled by the victim as being mentioned during her time at the alleged location of abuse (Epstein's mansion).

connections.description: Jennifer Freeman is the attorney representing the victim, referred to as 'M', and is advocating for her entry into the U.S. to provide evidence.
Paul Cassell facilitated the introduction between Jennifer Freeman's law firm and the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding the victim's case.
Dr. Silberg has been assisting the victim medically and has received evidence from her, including photographs and communications.
The victim alleges she was raped as a child at a location identified as Jeffrey Epstein's New York mansion.

events.title: Alleged Child Rape at Epstein Mansion
events.description: The victim alleges she was raped as a child (approximately age five) in a room at 9 East 71st Street, Manhattan, which is identified as Jeffrey Epstein's mansion. A photograph from this time is referenced.

events.title: Legal Request for Victim Entry into U.S.
events.description: Email correspondence between the Marsh Law Firm and the U.S. Attorney's Office requesting urgent assistance to bring an Israeli trafficking victim into the U.S. to provide information on the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Escalating Threats Against Victim
events.description: The victim reportedly faced increasing peril from her traffickers, including rape, burning, cutting, and death threats, to prevent her from cooperating.

locations: 9 East 71st Street, Manhattan, New York (Jeffrey Epstein's mansion)
keyFacts: An Israeli citizen and alleged long-term sex trafficking victim claims to have been raped as a child at Jeffrey Epstein's New York mansion (9 East 71st Street) around 1997.
The victim's attorneys provided a detailed description of the mansion's interior and a photograph allegedly showing the victim's rape in a room with a view consistent with Epstein's property.

The victim's traffickers are described as including her uncle, a member of a Russian crime family, and a Greek Orthodox Church priest, and they have recently subjected her to extreme violence and death threats to prevent cooperation.
Multiple attempts by the victim's advocates to provide evidence to the FBI and Homeland Security were reportedly met with resistance or dismissal prior to this correspondence.

The U.S. Attorney's Office responded that their ability to assist with immigration for a witness is very limited, typically requiring law enforcement to interview witnesses abroad or a lengthy process for trial testimony parole.
